document.masterDocTitle: A taxonomic revision of the southern African species of the subgenus Creightonella Cockerell (Apoidea: Megachilidae: Megachile Latreille)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A taxonomic revision of the southern African species of the subgenus Creightonella Cockerell (Apoidea: Megachilidae: Megachile Latreille)

Syn nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Discussion.
Smith ( 1853 )
described this species as
dorsata
and later he (
Smith 1879
) described
terminata
, both from South Africa . The latter was preoccupied by Morawitz ( 1875 ) and Mocsary ( 1887 ) renamed it
africana .
The type series of
terminata
is composite. The female syntype is synonymous with
Megachile (Pseudomegachile ) fulva
and will be discussed in a subsequent article, the male syntype is
dorsata .
D. Baker attached a lectotype label to the male syntype of
dorsata
but did not publish this designation. It therefore has no status in zoological nomenclature. The female will be designated as the lectotype of
M. fulva Smith
in a revision of Pseudomegachile that will be published presently. The type material has been studied.

Cameron ( 1905 a)
and
Strand ( 1911 )
described
harthula
and
capensiana
. They were synonymized with
dorsata
by
Pasteels ( 1965 )
. The type material of
harthula
and
capensiana
have been studied and the synonymies are here confirmed.

Friese ( 1922 )
described
arnoldi
from Zimbabwe . In his description he compared it with
M. kamerunensis ,
which belongs to the subgenus Callomegachile.
Pasteels ( 1965 )
, on the other hand, synonymized it with
M. ikuthaensis
, which is in the subgenus
Creightonella
. It closely resembles the type of
dorsata
, and is here synonymized with this species.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 10a–e.
Megachile dorsata
. a. Female face. b. Female habitus. c. Male face. d. Male habitus. e. Male T6–T7.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution (
Fig. 11
).
Megachile dorsata
appears to be endemic to southern Africa, and widely distributed throughout the Region.

Biology. This species visits the flowers of
Acacia karroo , Apalathus
chlorophila, Asteraceae ,
Blepharis mitracarpus
, Fabaceae and Polygalaceae .
